text: Maternal glucose crosses the placenta while maternal insulin does not; excess maternal glucose drives increased fetal insulin secretion.
Fetal insulin is anabolic and promotes fat deposition and somatic growth, contributing to macrosomia in the setting of chronic hyperglycemia.
Placental nutrient sensing pathways, including mTOR, can upregulate amino acid transport systems (system A and system L), supporting fetal overgrowth.
Obesity is associated with chronic low-grade inflammation and altered adipokines that worsen insulin resistance and vascular dysfunction, increasing long-term cardiometabolic risk.
Pregnancy increases insulin resistance; if beta-cells cannot compensate adequately, beta-cell stress and eventual dysfunction can push physiology toward type 2 diabetes.
